body.p: Let's say that Devcon gathered a huge crowds, filled up the narrow streets of Bogota, and a helpful community website was built to show all the evening events happening outside of the offical agenda. This website allows you to use the token on the website just so that you know which event you can participate.
The 3rd party website would look like this:
To do so, create an HTML page similar to the one we used on the issuer's site:
Observe that there is only one noticable difference, that is, the image of the logo:

So how does this 3rd party website know that the user have a ticket, and obtain the ticket details such as Ticket Number? This information is not stored on the 3rd party website, rather instead, it is either in the user's agent (if supported) or in the cookie of the ticket website.

This is achieved by the token negotiator, finding that the token is an attestation that is normally stored in the issuer's site's cooke, opening a connection to that website to obtain the token data. It's worth noting that such a connection does not require the issuer's site to have any server API, as it is done entirely in the client side.
